title: RL32608
content: The Intelligence Reform and Terrorism Prevention Act of 2004, enacted into law on December 17, 2004, included FISA provisions. It was originally introduced as the National Intelligence Reform Act of 2004 by Senator Susan Collins and Senator Joseph Lieberman. The bill passed the Senate with amendments on October 6, 2004. The Intelligence Reform and Terrorism Prevention Act of 2004, signed into law on December 17, 2004, amended the National Security Act of 1947 by replacing previous sections with new ones. The bill passed the House and Senate, with a conference report filed on December 7, 2004. The Intelligence Reform and Terrorism Prevention Act of 2004 amended the National Security Act by creating the position of Director of National Intelligence (DNI) and outlining their authorities and responsibilities. The DNI was given the responsibility to establish requirements and priorities for foreign intelligence information collection under FISA, and to assist the Attorney General in disseminating information derived from electronic surveillance or physical searches for foreign intelligence purposes. Section 102A(f)(8) of the National Security Act, as amended by P.L.108-458, clarifies the role of the Department of Justice and the Attorney General in relation to applications under the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act. Additionally, P.L. 108-458 amended FISA to replace "Director of Central Intelligence" with "Director of National Intelligence" and expanded the definition of "agents of a foreign power" to include individuals engaged in international terrorism activities. The new language in Sec. 6001 of the USA PATRIOT Act does not require a connection to international terrorist organizations. It will sunset on December 31, 2005, with exceptions for ongoing investigations. Sec. 6002 adds semiannual reporting requirements under FISA, with reports submitted to specific committees. The USA PATRIOT Act requires reports on the number of persons targeted for surveillance, breakdown by type of surveillance, individuals covered by orders, authorization for use of information in criminal proceedings, and legal interpretations before the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court.
